section.name: TPCS IN INT'L RELATIONS: THEORY/PRAC COUNTERINTEL
TPCS IN INT'L RELATIONS: THEORY/PRAC COUNTERINTEL
TPCS IN INT'L RELATIONS: TERRORISM & INSURGENCY

comments:
Topics for this course change each semester.  Please check the departmental website for the latest information regarding this course.

	Students for the most part enjoyed this “great” and “very interesting” course, with many saying they “learned so much” about world politics. Many students appreciated how the course incorporated current events into the curriculum, which was “a nice change from other introductory IR classes.” However, a few students did not feel this course was significantly better than the Introduction to International Relations course.

	Professor McGann was described by his students as “very knowledgeable,” which many students said helped make the course concepts more interesting. Students appreciated the “breadth of knowledge” he brought to each class, but many pointed out that “his ability to communicate the subject matter was not very good.” As this course lasted for three hours, students wished Professor McGann was less “disorganized” and could focus his knowledge more effectively to help students.

	Many students complained about the difficulty of the course compared to the information learned, with one saying “my grades probably don’t reflect my knowledge.” Tests were said to include information not covered in class, “which made them difficult,” and some felt that because this was “more difficult than an introductory course,” those without an IR background could face difficulty. It was recommended to those interested in attaining a “general understanding of International Relations nowadays” and particularly to those considering the IR major.
